sen.j: 定額僧（じょうがくそう）とは、古代律令制の寺院などに定められた一定数の僧侶あるいはその僧侶自身のこと。
sen.e: Jogakuso refers to a quota system for Buddhist monks under the "kodai ritsuryosei" (ancient East Asian system of centralized governance), or monks themselves under this system.

sen.j: 定額とは、定員のことを指し、律令制においては課税逃れを防ぐために朝廷は寺院に対して厳しく僧侶の定員遵守を求めた。
sen.e: The word 'jogaku' refers to 'a quota,' and under the ritsuryosei the Imperial Court compelled Buddhist temples to comply with a Buddhist monk quota to prevent them from wriggle out of taxes.

sen.j: 最古の例は奈良時代の天平13年（741年）に諸国の国分寺に対して僧20、同じく国分尼寺に対して尼10の定額を設定した例とされている。
sen.e: The oldest example of the Jogakuso is said to be a system adopted in the Tempyo era of the Nara period (in 741), whereby the jogaku of 20 Buddhist monks and 10 Buddhist nuns were introduced to "kokubunji" (a status of the state-supported provincial temples) and "kokubun-niji" (nunnery temple) of each province, respectively.

sen.j: 平安時代に入ると、弘仁13年（823年）東寺50人など各種の官寺に対して定額僧が定められた。
sen.e: In the Heian period, the Jogakuso was applied to various "kanji" (state-sponsored temples), such as To-ji Temple, which was ordered to have 50 jogakuso in 823.

sen.j: 定額僧の数は常に維持されることが望まれ、欠員が生じた場合にはこれを補う事が許された。
sen.e: Temples were expected to always maintain the allocated number of jogakuso and allowed to recruit new monks when there was a vacancy.

sen.j: また、定額を維持するために朝廷より供御米を与えてその財政を助けたという。
sen.e: Also, it is said that the Imperial Court aided temples with a portion of rice for the Emperor so that temples could maintain a jogaku.
